bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, January 17, 1901

div1.p: Howard congratulates Reed on the success of his work and mentions he will quote Reed's work favorably in his upcoming lectures. He asks Reed to use care in saying anything about his connection with the kerosene remedy. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, January 17, 1901
div1.p:
I have yours of the 13th, and am very much obliged
to you for the copy of General Order No. 6.

Yes, the results of your work are “enough to make a fellow
feel happy.” “Anopheles and Culex are a gay old pair.” I con-
gratulate you heartily on your success, which I think means great
good to the human race. I have had a beautiful figure of your
yellow-fever mosquito made, and expect that it will be published in
the Century Magazine for March. I am using a lantern slide of it
in a lecture which will be given a week from next Tuesday before the
Brooklyn Institute, and a little later at Cornell University, and,
as the Tonerlecture, before Georgetown University. In these lec-
tures I intend to praise your work in the highest terms.

If you have occasion to refer to any of my mosquito work, either
publicly or privately, please phrase carefully anything you may say
about my connection with the kerosene remedy. The facts are given
plainly in Bulletin 25. My credit in connection with kerosene
rests simply upon the announcement of exact experiments upon a
somewhat large scale; the discovery that adult mosquitoes, as well
as larvae, are killed by its application to breeding pools, and
upon my efforts as a propagandist in the face of foreign disbelief.
You will remember that Ross himself was incredulous as to the value
of kerosene until he used it at Sierra Leone, while Celli and Casa-
grandi, in their long report, practically discouraged its use.

LITTERA
SCRIPTA
MANET
* 1934 *
THE NATIONAL ARCHIVES
Washington, D. C.
RECORDS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF AGRICULTURE, Bureau of

div1.closer:
With renewed congratulations and thanks,
Sincerely yours, L.O. Howard Dr. Walter Reed, U. S. A.,
Columbia Barracks,
Quemados, Cuba.
